characters: EXT. RURAL ROAD- LATER THAT NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GASPING for BREATH continues, more relentless, harder, heavier and into the FRAME we SEE fragments, slowed into special motion, dreamlike, surreal: Dirty blonde hair lifts and tumbles;  Bubbles POP through the murky water;  A hand and then its attached arm swims, in trouble, tryin climb; And then floats as if disembodied, momentary; The SWIMMER drifts, then a brief effort twisting, signs o struggle; A leg pushes off the nothingness, threatened, an impossib fight; And the claustrophobic GASP, a last chocked back BREATH a other sounds begin to bleed in: the CRACKLE of a RADIO, a VOICES MURMURING and then more clearly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, please... Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water blurs opaque, into a murky veil of illusion and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cracked windshield of a blue Ford Fiesta.  The cloude form of the drowning SWIMMER is replaced by a small plast day-glo cross that sways as the Fiesta is lifted up on a truck hoist.  A PARAMEDIC jogs over to the car as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, hold on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fiesta stops its ascent.  The passenger side door ope and the Paramedic reaches in and snares the bopping cross

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Paramedic carries the plastic symbol over to a middle aged woman who's sitting on a stretcher, wearing a foam n brace and looking totally relaxed.  This minor fender-ben is an ignored sideshow on a quiet commercial street. As the woman reclaims her crucifix, a lanky MAN strides b over-coated against the fall weather.  We FOLLOW the MAN he rounds the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he walks on, he gazes out at a small Catholic Chur ahead. St. Ursula's is a modest seminary sitting adjacent to the Church.  And just in front, behind a chain link fence, is An asphalt playground used by the Church's pre-school program.  A group of CHILDREN play there in happy confusi watched by TWO FEMALE DAY-CARE WORKERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the day-care workers alternately pushes TWO KIDS o the swings, using one hand.  In her other hand, she holds cigarette.  Her clothes are worn, her sneakers frayed.  A simple gold cross hangs loosely from her neck.  She's got ancient holes in her ear lobes from another, earlier time but no longer any earrings.  This is MAYA LARKIN.  The ki she's pushing are singing "Frere Jacques" as they soar up down on the swings.   The second day-care worker, more nicely dressed, shoots M disapproving glances as she gives her swinging child mode pushes.   A Latino BOY walks up to Maya, both his shoes are untied his jacket's unzipped.  He points to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with mock severity) Look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves away from the swings, puts out the cigarette an stoops down, tying his shoes.  After she finishes, Maya watches him run back into the throng.  He dashes past the LANKY MAN, standing just ten feet away.  A powerful figur CLAUDE LAREAUX is in his sixties.  A stern, heavy express glances his face.  Maya stands back up slowly, looking at him, a more seriou expression on her face now.  She tosses her cigarette as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A non-descript Chrysler New Yorker as it winds its way do rural road.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: The car's driver is a fleshy man in his forties named JOH TOWNSEND.  He's anxious, a nail-biter, with the worn hand a worker.  Townsend's slightly nerve-wracked, but trying settle it all inside. Maya touches a fore-finger across her upper lip, warm, sh moves forward, covering heat vents with a cupped hand, uncomfortable, then finally flipping off the heat altoget which makes a final WHOOSHING GASP.  She POWERS OPEN the electronic window, a rough hum as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lareaux, in the back seat watching her.  Seated next to Lareaux is a dark haired, kind looking man in his 30's, JEREMY. Maya straightens the cuffs of her shirt sleeves - first t right, then the left.  Then she repeats it all.  Townsend notes the repetitive movement. And the RADIO is ON in the B.G.:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it says here in today's news that science is looking for a lost minute of daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what's that all about?  They have satellites now that can read our ATM receipts from outer space, but no one knows how we lost a minute of sunlight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they find that minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Townsend FLIPS OFF the radio.  There is an excruciatingly loud pause as everyone in the car sits quietly.  Then May turns sideways, leaning towards the backseat, and whisper Lareaux:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled by ROAR of passing truck) Why are you doing this to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Maya, but you'll understand when you see this man.  I really need your strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya silently acknowledges his remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subbed, in French) Ensemble pour toujours quio qu'il arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya reaches over, putting a soft hand on Townsend's knee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good seeing you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whish the circumstances were different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Maya turns back around in her seat, Lareaux looks up, Townsend's dart of worry in the rear view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Institutional 50's architecture.  Two-story building on picturesque grounds.  The Chrysler pulls up to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lareaux, his overcoat open, walks down the dim corridor. now see he's a priest.  He's wearing a black cassock with waist-high surplice (belt) and a narrow purple stole.  He carries a Bible.  Townsend, Maya and Jeremy are right bes him.  We see Jeremy is also a priest.  Townsend is carryi hard, black leather suitcase. Large windows, bordered by huge pillars, circumscribe the never-ending corridors.  Thick doors line the walls, each with a tiny observation window, filled in with octagonal patterns.  The foursome avoids looking directly at any of those windows. They pass other rooms, doors wide open, lined with severa beds each separated by worn curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting next to a door on this corridor is the hospital's Chief Resident Psychiatrist, DR. LESLIE ALLEN.  She's cas calm and intelligent.  A mature woman in her late 50's, s attractive, at peace with herself.  As she sips a cup of peppermint tea, she glances outside, through a window opposite her chair, at a huge old tree, the antithesis of sterile, prison-like environment inside.  She finds ways remain grounded in this place. As Lareaux and company approach, Dr. Allen switches her g and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands over a document) Your court order, Dr. Allen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing, makes transition) You know I'm not comfortable with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your patient is legally entitled to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This patient has been plagued with temporal lobe seizures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the patient's request, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistent) I'm aware of that, but I don't think he's in any condition to make requests.  I'm trying to appeal to your more...logical self, Father. (as she glances briefly at Maya, Townsend and Father Jeremy) I'm concerned about harm to my patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up the Doc's visual cue) Father Jeremy and Deacon John Townsend of St. Ursula's, and our associate, Maya Larkin. (off her look) Secular assistants are permitted if regarded as qualified.  Maya is eminently qualified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should join you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brusquely, interrupting) -- you wouldn't last five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting to it) Just open the door, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Doctor unlocks the door, Lareaux, Townsend, Father Jeremy and Maya file in.  Tense.  Cautious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has been painted hot pink.  The only furniture i large table, a chair and a bed.  A few books sit stacked the table: Albert Beutel's Cryptology, George Fleck's Sha Space and Claude Shannon's seminal Mathematical Theory of Communication, among others on advanced math. A slightly round man named HENRY BIRDSON is seated in the single restraining chair, compulsively writing numbers on yellow legal pad.  He wears green hospital pants and T-sh He looks up and smiles at all his visitors; a blinding, a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like the color in here? (glancing over barred windows) Spos'ed to be relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya and Townsend avoid looking at Birdson.  Maya straigh the cuffs of her sleeves.  Lareaux puts his Bible and a s crucifix on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Henry.  Do you know why we're here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdson nods, pleased with himself.  He stretches, langui drops his pad onto the table and yawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking forward to it.  Do you have a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lareaux As he catches Maya's gaze and as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya, who looks back at Lareaux, we:

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANOTHER PLACE, ANOTHER TIME
dialogues.text: Confined space.  Cheesy lace curtains drape across plexi sliding windows, a soft and constant WHISPERING of the "O Father" in the b.g. and we SEE: a younger Lareaux, longer hair, moving gracefully toward Maya,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not remember, O Lord, our sins or those of our forefathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya's face.  Wide-eyed at 16 years old.  In the b.g., Ma sister, stands rigid, afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do not punish us for our offences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An arm twisting almost out of its socket.  A SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And lead us not into temptation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREAMING CONTINUES.  Maya's on a bed, her head jerks sideways, involuntarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But deliver us from evil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crucifix follows its own shadow as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Townsend opens the black leather suitcase.  Inside: rolls duct and masking tape, two Bibles, three rosaries, a scapular, bottles of holy water and a gold Chalice, sitti in foam-laden velvet, for the Communion Eucharist. Maya quickly and expertly locks in Birdson's chair restraints.  Arms and legs. Father Jeremy pulls out a roll of duct tape, sealing the drawer shut.  Then, he sets up a portable tape recorder o the table.  Secures that as well. Birdson restrained, Maya pulls large square-cut pieces of blackout cloth out of the suitcase.  She grabs a roll of masking tape, TEARING two pieces of it with her teeth, ri off the roll.  A SEARING, jarring sound, unexpected every time.  Moving to the door, she immediately tapes a square blackout cloth over the observation window.  As the cloth drops, Dr. Allen's face disappears. Maya TEARS several more pieces of masking tape, continuin block out each window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours later, Dr. Allen is reassuring one of her patie She's calm, focused, helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to his stomach) My bowel is out.  I told you.  It's open, can't you see it!  My stomach's been eviscerated!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly an ORDERLY bursts around the corner, sprinting toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Allen and the orderly are jogging down the hallway. sound of SCREAMING can be faintly heard in the distance. Dr. Allen starts to run, leaving her patient, holding her stethoscope and pocket for anything that might fall out. BREATHING is slightly LABORED.  Her patient SCREAMS after her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (freaked) My bowel!!!  My stomach's been eviscerated!  And you won't help me!  HELP ME!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunned Laura Allen stands outside Birdson's room as TW MORE ORDERLIES frantically try to pry open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an order of meds.) Haldol, Cogenten, Atavan 5, 2 and 2 IM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the room, a CHORUS of TORMENTED VOICES is heard.  A hideous CACOPHONY that builds in intensity with each pass moment, punctuated by sharp explosions of wood and glass. It sounds like the room is being torn to pieces.  Along w everyone in it. Something heavy hits the door on the other side. Suddenly, the door BURSTS open.  The screaming instantly stops. Lareaux's at the door, pushing past the two orderlies and he collapses against a wall, Dr. Allen sees he's shaking, completely devastated.  Father Jeremy hurries after him, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, are you alright?  Can you get up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura Allen walks slowly over to the door.  And bracing herself, she leans forward and stares inside. The room is immaculate.  Nothing's damaged, not a stick o furniture is out of place.  Townsend and Maya slowly back out, careful not to look at Birdson who sits nonchalantly still tied to his chair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right here, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdson turns and stares at Dr. Allen with a chilling loo triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same languid posture, his own thought process etched in his brain) Come on in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Allen freezes.  Townsend moves past her.  Maya pulls door shut very quickly.  In her hand, she's grabbed Birds legal pad and one of his advanced math books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A restless CROWD clusters outside the entrance of the Manhattan courthouse, a mixture of press, public and security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the packed courtroom, the atmosphere is hushed and tense. Up on the witness stand, MR. SILBERMAN, a meek, reluctant witness, is testifying.  The DEFENSE ATTORNEY is relentle The JURY seems pretty intent on the testimony.  They eye:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Silberman, you worked with the defendant, George Viznick, for two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The accused, GEORGE VIZNICK.  He's in his early 20's, wit thick, black hair and strong features.  His neatly-presse suit and tie cannot disguise the fact he has the feral ey of an unrepentant psychopath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pacing in front of witness) And how would you describe him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.  Real quiet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on the day of the murders, his state of mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seemed...on edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the day of the murders (dramatic pause) what did the defendant request?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked to go home early.  He said he was bothered by all the people who kept telling him what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the jury) Tell the jury how many people work in that office with you and Mr. Viznick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a general MURMUR at this disclosure and... In the first row, wearing his press credentials like all the oth prominent members of the media, sits PETER KELSON.  Peter in his early 30's, fit, handsome, well-dressed, even seductive.  The ubiquitous success story, cynical, edgy a focused, he's all or nothing.  Peter takes notes in a lea book, graph paper, his own color-coded system, meticulous annotation.  He stares intently at the defendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman's arm and hand are visible as she writes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: piece of notebook paper covered with a nonsensical collec of vowels and consonants. We TILT UP to see Maya, who tosses the sheet onto a pile rejects.  She takes a sip of coffee.  Stale.  Maya reacts Finishes a cigarette.  Puts it out in a plain glass ashtr Lying next to her pack of cigarettes, a vintage Zippo, inscribed, "peace and fuck you." To Maya's left is Birdson's legal pad.  On it he has writ rows of numbers in neat, precise handwriting.  Maya has d red lines at regular intervals, showing a repeating patte of 11 numbers in a row. In the b.g., her used, always, "ON," 24" TV is airing a daytime talk show.  Guy describes his girlfriend's affair LIB.  Maya reacts to the insanity of the show. On the wall above Maya's table that serves as her desk, i varied collection of crayoned drawings from the children her day-care class, a postcard from Louisiana depicting N Orleans, a postcard-sized copy of Modigliani portrait of woman, and an old photograph of Maya and her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The page she just discarded "IF R EQUALS ONE" at the top letters of the alphabet matched up with a series of numbe Birdson's cryptology book is visible to Maya's right, as works off her newest piece of paper, labeled "IF S EQUALS ONE."  Maya moves to her mini fridge.  Looks inside.  Pul out a soda.  Pops the tab.  Spray startles her a moment.  Wipes off her fingers.  SLAMS the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comparing numbers and letters with a second piece of pape Maya notes that the first number, 24, gives her the lette "P."  The next number, 13, produces an "E."  She writes t down.  Flicks a long ash into a half-full ashtray.  Gulps air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya continues the coded procedure.  The next three numbe equal a "T," an "E" and an "R."  Finally spelling "Peter. Maya gets up.  Stretches.  Ashtray getting full.  Taps ou single cigarette from her shirt pocket.  Lights it.  EXHA deeply.  Excited and scared at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya checks her newest numbers, adding the letter "K."  T out her cigarette into an ashtray with earlier cigarette debris.  Small stacks of used up paper.  Maya stares at h results, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An explosion of CHATTER as the CROWD empties from the courtroom.  Many of the MEDIA rush to a press room across hall. As Peter heads that way, we see he enjoys some celebrity status.  Heads turn and fingers point as he goes by.  Pet stops a tall, Asian 26 year-old who's striding by with a thick packet. This is MICHAEL KIM, Peter's researcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kelson, here's the stuff you wanted on pathological narcissism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that psychic, what's his name, Szabo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can see you Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand) I think it's gonna be a waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to reassure his boss) The police used him as a witness in this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsmiling, but he likes Michael) I'll be at Bedford tonight, if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile) Nice suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes off, weaving his way through the crowds.  And he enters a MEN'S ROOM:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter saunters up to a urinal.  A rough looking man in hi late 40's comes out of a stall and approaches Peter.  Thi a tough cop named MIKE SMYTHE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, friendly) Hey!  Mr. big shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smile emerging) Mike.  Oh, the christening.  I meant to call...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (releases his hold) Yeah, right.  I don't know why I bothered inviting you guys.  I knew you wouldn't show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter finishes.  Zips up and goes to wash his hands.  Smy looks in the mirror, too, noticing a food stain on his sh He dabs at it half-heartedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Viznick's got a meet with his lawyer in the ayem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his interest is piqued) Really?  You know, seeing these guys away from the court, the facade slips.  You catch things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.  I've heard it before.  Just be sure you spell my name right.  Nine o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe hands Peter a tiny penlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you can see where you're going when you crawl up his asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Peter's smile, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The typical particle board and wallpaper set that looks better on the small screen.  Two chairs, one with Peter a one with the glossy blonde, perfectly styled, TV personal SALLY PRESCOTT. THE FLOOR MANAGER silently finishes the countdown as a ma up man touches up Peter before rushing off the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a part of today's story on the trial of mass murderer George Viznick, we welcome Peter Kelson, author of the current best-seller, VICIOUS INTENT.  Thank you for joining us, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for having me, Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, you're now writing a book about the Viznick case.  You seem to be making a career of studying sensational murderers.  I have to ask, how does it make you feel when you sit in courtrooms day after day, face to face with alleged killers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, long-term exposure to things like this tends to give you a sort of clinical understanding of the subject.  After awhile, you begin to make friends with it, so to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as if you are saying the closer you get to evil, the less evil it becomes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the less mystifying.  Good and evil are only illusions.  There is no such thing as evil with a capital "E."  That suggests some third party bad guy pulling all the strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit mesmerized) You're referring to the defense's efforts to prove that George Viznick is tormented by "demonic voices?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There weren't any voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even from some mental illness, as the prosecution asserts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if there's another cause for little voices?  No, Sally, Viznick's a manipulator, he's clever, he has what I call malignant narcissism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we all have a degree of narcissism, Sally, but a malignant narcissist is dangerously self-obsessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying he's legally sane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, George Viznick is in the grayest of gray areas in the sanity spectrum.  Viznick is not psychotic.  He's simply unable to submit to any higher authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning, Viznick's a man who answers to no one.  Not even God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps ahead of her) Right.  If you believe in God.  As a narcissist, Viznick couldn't blame himself for the alleged murders.  He created the voices after the fact.  In order to avoid the simple truth that there is no outside force that guides George Viznick and that George Viznick needs to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (personally interested) And what about you?  What about Peter Kelson?  Where is your moral compass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is momentarily serious, interior, then the brief sl smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, lucky for me, I'm not on trial, Sally.  However, I like to think I'm the actual needle on the compass.  Morality is which way you're facing.  The needle always points north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally smiles, a sucker for that sort of crap.  INT. CONTROL BOOTH - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TECHNICAL DIRECTOR leans over to a CAMERAMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally's hot for this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall attractive female P.A. overhears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more taken with him than she thought) Peter...Kelson, ah, thank you for joining us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure, Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's a cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally leans forward to Peter and proffers a copy of his b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you sign it for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashes a killer smile) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Range Rover double parks in front of an immense Catholi Church.  Peter gets out. Across the street, a group of Orthodox Jews walk by.  On steps of the church is an exotic woman, stylish in a yell Prada dress with a matching yellow nylon zip jacket.  CLA VAN OWEN hugs the collar to her neck against a sudden win guest.  She's a magazine stylist and Peter's girlfriend. Peter meets Claire on the street, he grabs hold of her, relaxed.  He kisses her deeply.  Claire still reacts, tho it's been a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously in love) I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing it) Do you think they have a room here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at the possibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd your interview go?  I'm sure you charmed the hell out of Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a talk show host.  They can't be charmed.  By definition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire slides an arm through Peter's.  Then, she reaches suddenly kissing him hard on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Claire walk down the center aisle, dwarfed by t vast vaulted ceiling and rosette stations of the cross. the Travertine and Terrazzo altar, there's a solemn atmosphere.  Choir practice is just about to end and the SINGERS are CHANTING A-CAPELLA in Latin. Standing before them, keeping time and tone, is FATHER JA MCKENZIE, a good-natured priest in his late fifties.  He Peter and Claire and lets the choir practice wind down.  Singers begin to collect their music as Father James move toward his visitors, happy to see them, as always.  He gi Peter a strong hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you doing? (to Claire) Looking lovely as always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James turns to the choir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, you shrieking harpies, enough of that racket.  Be off with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir makes their way out in several directions, shak their heads at Father James' corny humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you have to sin tonight, try to make it something original.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROAN from the group at the bad pun.  Claire and Peter smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father James carefully and ritualistically removes his vestments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is driving up the West Side Highway, relaxed, an ar out the window.  Claire is beside him. James sits in the back, peaceful, meditative, as the tree lining the road move by in a sort of blurred landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between your book sales and this TV thing, there's going to be no living with you.  And let me guess, you boiled God down to a conceit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how I feel.  The world is random.  The only certainty I believe in is death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given all that's happened, I understand.  The world is random, but then there's faith.  Where are you in death without it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a car cuts Peter off.  Peter slams on his breaks Close call.  Claire's purse falls off her lap.  Lipstick spills out.  She steadies herself against the dash with a hand.  James is pressed forward into his seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a...jerk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter resumes driving, mildly irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting back to the conversation) It's great of you to let William and Susan stay at the house until he gets on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting across the earnestness) It's Susan's cooking, Claire.  That's why Uncle James lets them stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense, it's all of our home. (to Claire) So how's work treating you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frustrating.  Form over content.  Everything's so retro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if Peter here would hop off his laurels long enough to marry you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the wheel, Peter gazes straight out at the road.  No expression.  But he cringes inwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting for Peter's sake) ...you wearing a watch, Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  It's exactly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he slides back his sleeve as Clair looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you check the century hand for me?  Mine seems to be ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James LAUGHS.  Peter shakes his head.  The notion of commitment more private to him that to his more expansive uncle.  Claire inadvertently glances at Peter, then she l out her window, an awkward, inward moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya's TV is on, as usual.  She SNAPS open a bag of edama soy nuts, popping them into her mouth, while a lit cigare sits in the glass ashtray next to her.  She eats and smok alternately.  Feet up, socks on.  Maya's flipping through Manhattan white pages, looking for the last time, Kelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caption has been flashed onscreen: PETER KELSON, AUTHOR OF VICIOUS INTENT. Sally Price is interviewing Peter Kelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya glances up and she can't believe what she reads.  Ta her a moment to pull it all in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as a narcissist, he couldn't blame himself.  He created the voices after the fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya shoves a pen between her teeth, while she tears off sheet of paper.  She immediately scribbles the name of th book on the torn piece of paper. As Maya looks back up at the TV, a dart of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A table showcasing the current best-sellers prominently features Peter's book, VICIOUS INTENT. Maya reaches in and picks up a copy.  Immediately flips t the jacket flyleaf at the back.  Reads a moment and as sh dos we see the bio: "born in Bedford, NY, a crime writer whose own parents were murdered..." Maya heads to a payphone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Townsend sits at his meticulously maintained PIANO, which is in sharp contrast to the otherwise rundown surroundings.  The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya?  What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll explain everything later.  Can you meet me tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a large house.  Peter pulls up and HONKS.  As he, Ja and Claire get out of the car, they walk past an old swin hanging from an enormous tree.  Childhood remnant.  Expecting them, a man in his late 30's wearing heavy rimm GLASSES moves out of the house.  This is WILLIAM, Peter's brother, followed by his wife, SUSAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About time, I'm starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs Peter in a bear hug.  Peter looks uncomfortable. And as he pulls free, he collides inadvertently with a lo hanging tree branch.  As it starts to bleed, Peter sucks his lip.  The swing moves slightly in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could use a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got martinis on ice and I grabbed some good bottles from the cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone except Susan troops into the dining room, where impressive dinner awaits them.  They take their places be their respective chairs.  A routine.  BUZZ of conversatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Peter, I missed your show.  How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, we taped it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they got my best side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan moves in, carefully balancing a few ceramic platter and then she bends over the table, squeezing the last pla onto a huge wooden table already covered with plates of various food.  Then, she sits down herself.  Takes a litt breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.  If you need anything else, get it yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock distress) Susan, I don't see any salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan) You know, I made a reservation at Marco's for Peter's birthday dinner, but maybe you should cater it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time did you make it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Father James) Eight.  That okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I want your advice on what to get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immediately to William, kind) I don't want you spending any money on me.  Not right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter) Peter, in life, you should never deny the giver the pleasure of the gift. (amused, to Claire) All those years raising him.  They seem to have had absolutely no effect.  Now William, at least he listened to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's eat already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father James bows his head and immediately, the family follows.  A signaled, almost unconscious gesture known to everyone.  They all look down except Peter.  Claire gives an annoyed glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless us, oh Lord, for these thy gifts through they bounty through Christ our Lord.  And a special blessing for Peter and William's mother, Andrea, and their father, Jack, in whose memory we gather here every year.  May their souls and the souls of the faithfully departed rest in peace.  Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stark silence as Peter and William remember.  Claire lo at Susan.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Will, remember that dream I used to have over and over again when I was little, about the bear and the mountain.  You know, right after...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William nods "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...well, you know, I really think the trial's getting to me, because I've been having this weird dream every night.  Only this time, of course, it's much different...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's looking at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never said anything to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably trivial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recurring dreams are never insignificant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll tell you.  I'm reading a book - I can't remember what the book is when I wake up - but I realize halfway through it's something I've written.  Or will write.  Anyway, I get to the end of the book and I'm feeling very satisfied and I close the cover to read the title and it only says "x-e-s".  Three letters.  For some reason, that makes me feel great, and I wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around at the silenced table, holding back a smirk, a moment, then) Peter, "x-e-s" is "sex" spelled backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More silence, then James bursts out LAUGHING.  Then Susan can't gold it back and then William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around, big smile turning into LAUGHTER) What can I say?  I'm not a master of the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that sends everyone into an uncontrollable fit of LAUGHTER and as they're all in various states of choked b hysterics, suddenly William's LAUGHING becomes seriously uncontrolled and then: William's head involuntarily jerks backward, his eyes beg to roll up. Susan is first to notice, while LAUGHTER continues in the b.g. and she leaps to catch him. As William starts to tip over backward in his chair, Pete then realizes and together, Susan and Peter ease William the floor and turn him on his side. James grabs a pillow from an armchair in the room, shovin under William's head and... As William's epileptic attack winds down slightly, Susan looks up at James:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long time since his last seizure.  I guess we've got to adjust his medication again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadowy figures of Maya and John Townsend can be seen almost in silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are you thinking we should do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've filed a report with Father Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of good that'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need all the help we can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've dealt with these people before, Maya.  They're not going to help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see Father Frank in the morning.  There's nothing to be done until then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on edge) Alright, Maya.  We'll do it your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A troubled John Townsend prays to God for answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER FRANK, a sweet-faced priest in his 40's, is confer with two church officials.  We TRACK him as he exits the office and cross through to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JANITOR polishes the marble of the ornate altar.  Fathe Frank enters and pauses a moment to watch the man at work

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget to polish the brass afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seminary has a small, planted, meditative garden, sho horned in behind the rectory buildings. Maya sits on a simple wooden bench, her tiny cross glinti off sunlight.  Her eyes are closed and her head is tilted toward the sun. Maya snaps out of her reverie, as Father Frank approaches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kind, but resolved) Maya, the Diocese has rejected your report.  And I must say, I agree with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JET ROARS overhead, DEAFENING momentary noise.  Father Frank looks up a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comforting tone) I don't mean to belittle you, but we've been through this before.  Satan is not what you think he is.  Satan is not some creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't there.  Give me time to get some proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Maya.  I'm trying to get us into the next century and you insist on this medieval nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you really believe in God, why is it so inconceivable that his enemy is just as real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya, for the last time, I will not tolerate these obsessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anxious, Maya rubs her cross between a thumb and forefing distractedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya crosses through the dim hallway and heads up the sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright, clean bathroom with new fixtures and fluorescen lights.  Maya comes in, trying to contain her frustration Turns the water on.  She watches the water a moment.  The puts her hands in.  Cool on her wrists.  Splashes her fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (despairing) Stupid man.  I can't do this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, she hears something.  It's faint, but unmistakable - the sound of SCRAPING METAL ON METAL.  The stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: Maya faces all six stalls.  She walks to the first one, pushes open the door.  It's empty.  She repeats this at t second stall, the thirds, the fourth, the fifth.  All are vacant.  Now the last one.  She pauses just a second. The lights HUM.  She pushes it open.  It's empty.  Distur she turns back to the sink and as she looks down, the wat flows instantly backwards, disappearing up into the fauce She turns back again, watching the room change from prist to rotting decay.  The stalls behind her have changed.  T doors are closed again.  They're battered, chipped, scarr Rusty water flows from underneath.  She whirls around.  O the stall directly behind her, the letters "X" "E" and "S have been scratched into the metal in loose, flowing scri At the same time, the lights go dim.  The HUM is uneven, menacing.  Alarmed, Maya closes her eyes, then opens them The vision remains.  Her breathing gets lighter, faster.  Fingers appear on the top of the stall door behind her. door is pulled open.  A man in inside, wearing hospital clothes.  It's Henry Birdson.  His eyes bore into hers. got a knife in his right hand.  Petrified, she stares bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leers and nods, "Yes I am."  He steps toward her.  Eve instinct in her body screams at her to run.  But she stay put.  And we HEAR A CHOKED BACK BREATH and Birdson slowly extends his knife, just inches from her face. Closer to her face.  Then closer still.  Until the tip of blade is slowly creeping toward Maya's eye.

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: of the tip of the blade, literally millimeters from her pupil.  Closing painfully slow.  Maya braces herself.

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: of the tip of the knife now only a hair away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdson.  He smiles.  And THRUSTS.  She suddenly reaches and grabs for the blade.  The lights "flare" horrifyingly bright for a split second.  We hear a surreal distortion Maya's voice crying out. And "Birdson" vanishes.  Maya's looking at a pristine bathroom, its unmarked stall doors pulled tight.  Victori but drained, she slumps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside Father Lareaux's Spartan room at the seminary, Lar lies in bed, his face turned towards the wall.  He's MUMBLING.  Maya has pulled herself together and sits by t bed with Father Jeremy and an irritated Father Frank.  In the b.g., John Townsend is urgently riffling the books papers on Lareaux's desk.  Most of which we SEE are about demonic possession. Unknown to anyone, Townsend slides two of the books under coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Maya) Leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya doesn't want to hear that.  She leans closer.  The f wound of her childhood pressed back into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (compassionately) Father, it's me, Maya.  Tu m'entends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lareaux rolls over and looks at her.  The change in his appearance is shocking.  His eyes are red-rimmed and his expression is unfocused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a nursery rhyme cadence) ...the ark sank, the sun set, the ark sank again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, I'm right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a child) ...the ark sank, the sun set, the ark sank again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his eyes are wild.  Father Frank turns to Maya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not going to respond...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya slowly backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor's concerned he may never come out of this dementia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will.  He has great faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But bad judgement.  And now you see how dangerous the consequences can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya moves over to a silent John Townsend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John.  I've got to head back to the city. (to Father Jeremy) Would you page me if there's any change whatsoever? (Maya hurriedly writes her pager number down for Jeremy) Anything, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) I wish I could help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya smiles sweetly at Father Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya and Townsend confer down the hall from Lareaux's roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's useless...look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't back out on me now.  We need to be sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agitated) Sure of what?  Who cares if this guy is devoid of faith or sleeps over a pentacle?  Results are what Lareaux would want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya stares intently at Townsend.  Father Jeremy approach from down the hall, aware of the tension between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to face it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, John, I'm facing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not waiting until it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Townsend walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he going to be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A list of names, all doctors.  Some have bene crossed off And as we PULL BACK, we see Maya's on the phone on a Bedf main drag and, as she DIALS, she pivots in the booth, anx thought process, a pencil being lobbed between two finger Suddenly, a VOICE over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hi, I'd like to make an appointment for Peter Kelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she waits, she pivots back around again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: no, he's not a new patient.  Okay, thank you, bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya crosses off another doctor's name from her list.  DR in two more quarters, as several sit stacked by the phone Maya glances around.  As she checks her list, TAPPING out another number, she takes a deep BREATH as she sees A MAN walking his dog.  The dog suddenly stops, squats an takes a greasy shit right on the sidewalk.  Maya can't believe it, wants to say something but the line picks up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refocusing) Hi, I'd like to make an appointment for Peter Kelson. (a beat) No, he's a returning patient.  You don't.  Thanks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crosses off another name.  DROPS in two more quarters.  T out another number.  Maya bends the silver phone cord distractedly, back and forth awhile, and as the line pick back up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rote) Hi, I'd like to make an appointment for Peter Kelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelson, hold on a second...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya waits anxiously as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Kelson hasn't been here in awhile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause, while Maya listens, then, repeating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.  Ten o'clock?  Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya hangs up, circling a name and address on her list, a as she takes off as we:  INT. BEDFORD GENERAL PRACTITIONER - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor's Office.  Formica reception desk.  Small waiting room.  Few PATIENTS sit, reading magazines, waiting for t doctor. Maya walks in the door, moving to the rectangular opening the check-in desk. Young receptionist, visibly pregnant, castors around to M handing her the clipboard, standard procedure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it in, but ignoring it) I don't know how to begin, by boyfriend... (looks around, in whisper) my ex-boyfriend.  The last time we were together, he, shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya's on the verge of tears.  The receptionist knows wha coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took one of those home pregnancy tests, but I don't want to tell him.  I'm RH negative.  My blood type is negative... (starting to cry) If he's RH positive, I'll have to terminate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Maya Kleenex) How many weeks are you honey/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen.  The last time, can you believe it?  This is how he says "Goodbye?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (registers alarm) You need his blood-type.  Like right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ready to let receptionist connect the dots) Well I know he's come here before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) Peter...Peter Kelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffling) I didn't know what else to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment, Maya's anxiety increasing, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (castors back to Maya) You're in luck.  Says Peter Kelson's an... AB negative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya has a moment of confusion as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two negatives always make a positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overjoyed, huge smile) Oh, thank you, thank you so much!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya enters a small reception area.  Behind its counter s an elderly DEACON and a SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have some questions regarding the baptismal records for one of our new constituents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the person's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Kelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the normal activity of a Soho street.  The camera pulls back and into Peter's office where see Peter workin his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a writer's domain.  Books everywhere.  Stacked and shelved in an obvious order, by size and subject.  There also several silver and leather-framed photos of Peter an Claire with known literary celebrities.  At the large gra and birch desk, an exhausted Peter switches off his compu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hits INTERCOM) Mrs. Quintana, let's go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His secretary, MRS. QUINTANA, appears in the doorway.  Sh a strong-willed Latino in her forties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plan to. (beat) You want a tip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme guess.  The lottery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I can just feel the numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what they say.  You have the same chance of winning whether you play or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch.  One day, I'll hit the jackpot, get the big house, car, clothes.  I'll have more money than God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Y yo tendre mi propria secretaria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNAPPING off the lights in her office.  And in the b.g., fragmentary sounds of a party going on somewhere down the hall, in another office.  A moment, then her outer office door slams. Peter goes back to work at his desk.  Finishing up.  Anot moment and he hears Mrs. Q's door PRESS BACK OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) What'd you forget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.  Peter looks up.  He waits, then continues t put his things away in preparation for leaving.  After a moment, he glances up to see MAYA standing in the doorway She's taken pains to look attractive.  Her best clothes. looks great.  A simple beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Kelson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (observes everything about her) Yes... and you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly flirtatious, gregarious) I saw you on television yesterday.  You were brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Do you work in the building?  You coming from the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya takes the chair opposite Peter's desk.  He stands waiting.  A little put off by her forwardness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that malignant narcissism was not evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not pure evil.  That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And also that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Listen, I'm sorry, but I'm running late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That there is no such thing as evil with a capital "E."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the most popular opinion, but yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I told you I was a malignant narcissist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intrigued, Peter stops what he's doing and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narcissist doesn't admit it.  It's the extreme of self-denial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Peter's comment) And I also believe in God and the Devil.  In fact, I know they exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, by saying that, you're acknowledging the existence of a higher power.  Which, to a narcissist, is impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I murdered my parents, Mr. Kelson.  And while they deserved it, I still went to confession the following Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter leans back in his chair.  Studies her carefully.  Doesn't really know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooooooh-kayyyyyy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the end, the jury saw it my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then it all seems to be working out for you.  Listen, Ms...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember Henry Birdson?  The math professor who won the Salwen Medal, then went home and killed his family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) What's that got to do with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last week the Catholic Church certified him as genuinely possessed.  You realize how rarely they make that ruling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exorcism was just held for Birdson.  It failed.  Disastrously.  Which means there's still a demonic spirit present in his body. (then) I was wondering, perhaps you'd like to go meet Henry.  He's pretty amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On television, you seemed so sure of yourself.  If you're really that confident, you'd be willing to let someone prove you wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world would be so much simpler if it were all just about good and evil.  Unfortunately I find it much more slippery and elusive place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intrigued by Peter's mind) Well, I think it's very simple.  Here's a tape of Birdson's exorcism. (drops tape on Peter's desk) I'll be at the Public Library.  Tomorrow at 2... if you want to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya rises and heads for the door.  Seductive.  A certain power in her clarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe that murder and murderers are the most interesting proving ground for these kinds of questions.  Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter knows he agrees, but before he can respond, she's g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small, elegant building in Chelsea.  Scaffolding covers exactly half of the exterior.  Building's being sandblasted.  CONSTANT GRATING NOISE.  Work area's floode artificial spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks past the building's doorman, JOSEF.  Eastern European, mid-60's, formal and outwardly polite.  Josef n a professional "good evening" to Peter who acknowledges J as he continues toward the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating noise) Great sound.  How the hell do you live with that all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josef laughs politely, he likes Peter.  Peter presses the elevator button and waits, sticking his free hand in a po and as he pulls out Maya's tape, he remembers as... The BELL to the elevator DINGS and the door SLIDES open.  Peter inspects the tape with some curiosity, then stuffs back into his pocket, momentarily lost in thought.  Stepp into the elevator, he suddenly PULLS in a breath, startle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Levotsky, jeez you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His comment is directed at an impossibly-elderly woman, M LEVOTSKY.  She scowls as though this was the only express her parents could afford for her.  She holds her cane wit her right hand, with her left she tries to balance her antiquated laundry cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when Peter reaches for the cart, she waves him off wi deepening in her scowl that we don't want to see get any deeper.  The elevator door slides SHUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter puts the key in his door, apartment 5-A.  Glancing the hall, he sees Mrs. Levotsky struggle toward her door. she feels his stare, she turns slowly around and to Peter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you look at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pissed off, Peter shoves the key into its lock and goes i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark, except for refracted light from the building opposite.  Peter FLIPS on the interior lights and we can lots of money has been spent here; the interior's warm an tasteful.  It's eclectic, evolved.  Works of art pepper t surroundings.  A small, luminous aquarium sits by the ent wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drops food into aquarium) Hi guys. (calling) Claire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter heads into the open kitchen.  The flood lights on t outside cast strange, distorted shadows of people moving. Peter reaches down behind the refrigerator and fishes out pack of cigarettes.  He turns on the vent over the stove lights up, blowing the smoke directly up into the vent, tapping the ashes directly down the sink drain.  Unseen b Peter, a cigarette ash drops and lands on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter reappears a moment later, holding a bottle of beer. Takes off his jacket, laying it on top of the sofa.  He m over to the CD player where he flips on some contemporary music.  Then he takes a long swallow of beer and sits bac down into the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUMP, BUMP, BUMP.  Peter looks up at the wall, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Levotsky, we really need to have a couple brews and talk one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes the remote to the CD, turns up the volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights on the equalizer.  They go from the middle ran of green and yellow up to the orange and occasionally red indicating the volume is pushing "complain." In response, Mrs. Levotsky BANGS on the wall a little har

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A luminous fly-fishing lure, with a black thread body and wings of transparent green and yellow fabric.  It's locke a tiny vice, its barbed hook shining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, all concentration, is bent over a magnifying glass using two tiny precision hooks to wrap thread onto the lu He's at a table in the corner of the living room.  A colo collection of finished lures are displayed on his work ar below a watercolor of a man fly-fishing. Peter gets frustrated as he repeatedly tries to hook a th and misses.  In the b.g., a leather framed photo of Peter with his parents at an exquisite lake.  Peter pushes hims back from the table.  Takes a beat.  Walks over and picks the tape Maya gave him. He studies it for a second.  Then he naps off the CD play puts the tape on the cassette deck and hits "play."  Ther no sound.  He turns the volume way up.  There's a HUM, bu nothing else.  Annoyed, Peter hits "forward," then "play. Still nothing.  He pushes the volume to the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) What'd you expect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this P.O.V., the HORRENDOUS ROAR of Birdson's EXORCI is heard.  Mrs. Levotsky raises her cane in desperation..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this P.O.V., the tape continues to play soundlessly. Peter hears rapid POUNDING from Mrs. Levotsky's apartment Faster, more frantic.  The pictures on his wall SHAKE violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...come on, lady!  Give me a break!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Levotsky's POUNDING continues for some time.  Finall ending in a booming THUD.  Peter looks up at the wall, wa then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little cough syrup will do ya, eh, granny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter bends down to snap off the tape, failing to notice the lights on the equalizer are PUSHING HIGH into the red all channels.  He turns off the tape and puts on a Sonny Rollins CD.  The music begins at an EAR-PIERCING volume.  Peter scrambles to turn it down, then flops back onto the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door CLICKS, then opens.  Claire moves in carrying ba of take-out.  She sees Peter dozing on the couch. Claire kneels beside him, gives him a kiss and Peter leap out of his sleep with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shi... Sorry, honey.  I was having the weirdest dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't want to go over it) Weird.  The book again.  Sex spelled backwards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must really be slacking off.  Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...sure...I...what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sushi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire is clearing her plate as Peter picks at the remain a sushi dinner.  Claire notices the cigarette ash Peter dropped earlier, picking it up and smearing the ash betwe her fingers.  She shoots a glance at Peter, but does not comment on her discovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it's already starting to get dark so early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there was a guy on the radio today trying to explain why we're losing daylight.  Quarks and dark matter, things like that.  Even how daylight savings has caught up with us over the last hundred years and our universal watch is just fast, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire looks up, seeing Peter is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  It's just...a strange woman waltzes into my office today.  Tells me she murdered her parents and can prove Satan exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Did she waltz in or fly on little bat wings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unacknowledged) Says she can get me in to see this killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that you're on TV, you're a magnet for all the wackos out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire sees Peter's thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Peter, you're going to pursue this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees her concern) No.  Of course not. (checking out the food) Mmmm.  Anago.  My favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Viznick's lawyer is seated at the table.  He's impatient.  A door opens.  A manacled Viznick is brought by two GUARDS.  His orange prison jumpsuit is badly rippe back.  A few bruises are visible on his torso.  Viznick stands impassively as his restraints are unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, come in. (sees his client) What the hell happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is.  If the guards did this, we can file charges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the guards. (smiles) Some of the prisoners are easily disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to tell me who did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viznick leans closer to the lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take care of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go make a stink.  Sit tight.  I'll make sure you get a change of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attorney exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Smythe enter a small room with a few chairs.  I dominated by an oversized, one-way window that allows the look onto the adjacent interrogation room.  A speaker sys lets them hear what's going on, but they can't be heard. GUARD enters with a replacement outfit.  Viznick stands passively as his restraints are unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this side, the window is a mirror.  In its reflectio Viznick is seen peeling off his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems George isn't making too many friends in lockup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, look at that sweet face.  You'd never guess he killed nine people.  I'm gonna get my smokes.  Be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too old to smoke.  Won't be able to shoot hoops with your grandkid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smythe gives Peter a dirty look, ignoring the advice, as exits.  Peter looks back down at his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck's that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter looks up and sees the shocked Guard staring at Viznick's bare back.  It's covered by an enormous tattoo depicting Christ hanging upside down from the bottom of a cross, pinned there by a nail through his feet.  His dang arms end in stumps.  His severed hands are still nailed t the crossbar.  The effect is horrific yet mesmerizing.  A Peter watches, Viznick puts on a shirt, covering the tatt and then sits with his back to Peter.  The cops and guard exit.  Peter moves closer to the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuous) You don't fool me, Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viznick's head tilts.  Ever so slowly, he turns around un his eyes meet Peter's.  He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viznick's looking at the mirror.  His reflection looks ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's thrown.  Is he seeing what he thinks he's seeing? Spooked, he moves three feet to his right.  Viznick's sta follows him without hesitation.  Perplexed, Peter moves a and again, the killer continuing to track him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter looks up as Smythe re-enters the viewing room.  See Peter's fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking right at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men turn to face Viznick, who is now gazing placidly few inches to the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offers Peter a cigarette) I'll quit, maybe you should start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A docile Viznick pivots in his chair and yawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe...my imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter gives Smythe a short smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter crosses the street from the police station.  He ste out between two parked cars and immediately into the path a speeding van.  Suddenly, a hand reaches out, jerking hi back.  The van ZOOMS by, missing Peter by inches.  He loo at his savior, it's a CRANKY middle-aged woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acerbic expression) Wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stares at her as she walks by.  She turns, sticks o her tongue at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter ascends.  The button for the fifth floor is illuminated.  The elevator chimes.  He looks up and sees elevator stopping on the fourth floor.  He steps back to room.  It's Claire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what are you doing here in the middle of the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgot my car keys.  What are you doing on the fourth floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spaced out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a nice surprise.  Should I hit the "stop" button?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans in and gives her a sexy kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya's waiting.  A group of Japanese TOURISTS including several women in kimonos, a group of Catholic school GIRL uniform and a mounted POLICEMAN are part of the street sc Maya stamps out her cigarette as Peter pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they take off, Peter motions to his cupholder, where t coffees sit securely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up coffee) Thanks.  I'm glad you came.  Take the Williamsburg Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Maya glances over at Peter, she's slightly fascinated. Peter remains reserved, but polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...what did you think of the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you gave me the wrong one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly irritated) It was blank.  Nothing on it.  You gave me the wrong one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya takes a sip of coffee to conceal her shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure?  There was nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cranked it all the way up.  Nothing but hum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya's unnerved.  Peter sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what'd I miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering well) You're right.  I must've made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya and Peter are walking towards the entrance.  She's touching the cuffs of her sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Maya turn the corner and approach the door to Birdson's room.  An ORDERLY is walking with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we wait for the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she won't mind. (re: the door) It's not locked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessary...anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya and Peter enter the room.  Followed by the orderly. motionless Birdson lies on his bed.  Eyes closed.  His body curled backwards at a horribly severe angle and arms are wrapped tightly around his torso.  He's a grueso sight.  An IV TUBE is taped to his wrist and an EEG is attached to his head.  The brain wave monitor indicates n activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beaming Dr. Allen walks in.  She's a little starstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kelson, what a pleasure to meet you.  I have to say your instincts about the criminally insane are impeccable.  I am a fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a compliment coming from you, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Allen realizes Maya's beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter) When your secretary called, she made no mention of her coming, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at Maya) My secretary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're aware that this woman was party to the so-called exorcism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wasn't, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know I never felt Mr. Birdson needed anything but professional psychiatric care.  And then, minutes after they left, he suffered a stroke.  He's comatose.  No brain wave activity at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Allen adjusts Birdson's IV unit, re-taping an already swollen hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't believe his condition is the result of anything supernatural?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.  They put him through severe mental stress.  Causing this aneurysm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Allen, could you please tell Mr. Kelson what you heard as you tried to enter Mr. Birdson's room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Maya) I certainly hope you're not lending any credence to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressive) What did you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter looks at Dr. Allen questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patient was in great distress.  Naturally he was...yelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And was he in distress when you opened the door?  Or was he sitting here, relaxed, at this table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) There is a medical explanation for everything that happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boring in) You heard voices, you know you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a silence in the room.  Dr. Allen stares at Maya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounded like a hundred people to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya, Peter and Dr. Allen turn and look at the orderly.  Peter's shocked by the orderly's admission.  Glances back Dr. Allen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already said, Mr. Birdson was agitated.  Victor, why don't you go and check on the patient in room 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her tone is frighteningly friendly.  The orderly leaves.  Peter looks at Maya, then Dr. Allen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curious) Just describe it to me, the scene, when you came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Peter speaks, Maya has an uncomfortable feeling.  She turns and sees Birdson STARING AT HER.  Eyes wide open.  Above him, the monitor's still showing no brain wave activity.  He grins at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Dr. Allen turn quickly - as Birdson snaps his e back shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just woke up.  He's awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they see is a motionless man in exactly the same position as before.  The monitor's still showing nothing steady, horizontal waves. Dr. Allen shakes her head at Maya's outburst.  Dismissive her altogether and then to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised at you, Mr. Kelson.  And now I'm afraid I'm going to have to ask the two of you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter drives out the hospital gates.  Maya's with him.  T radio is on.  Peter's angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you get off pretending to be my secretary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
